love.question: Someone says "I miss you 😔" but {name} just stares at the screen. What's going through your mind?

options.text: Nothing. I literally feel nothing 🧊
Annoyed because I don't know what to say back 😑
Analyzing if they really mean it or just saying it 🧐
I should reply something nice even if I don't feel it 👍

love.question: It's been 3 months and {name} hasn't felt 'butterflies' for their partner. Is this normal?

options.text: Yes! The honeymoon phase is just marketing 🙄
Maybe they're just comfortable, that's better than drama 😌
No, they should feel something... anything! 😳
They should break up - no spark means no future 💔

love.question: {name} always initiates conversations with their crush who replies with one-word answers. What's the move?

options.text: Keep trying! They're just shy 🥺
Take the hint and stop messaging 👋
Match their energy with equally boring replies 😶
Ask directly if they're interested or not ❓

love.question: {name}'s partner says "I love you" but {name} doesn't feel ready to say it back. What should they do?

options.text: Say it back anyway to avoid awkwardness 😬
Say "thank you" and change the subject 👀
Explain honestly that they're not there yet 🗣️
Ghost them because it's too much pressure 👻

love.question: {name} has been dating someone for 6 months but still doesn't miss them when they're apart. Is this a red flag?

options.text: Yes! That's definitely not love ⛔
No, independence is healthy in relationships 💪
Maybe they're just not the anxious attachment type 🧠
They should feel something... otherwise what's the point? 🤷

love.question: {name} feels emotionally disconnected in relationships. What might help?

options.text: Finding someone more exciting who gives them butterflies 🦋
Therapy to explore why they shut down emotionally 🧠
Accepting that they're just not the emotional type 🤷
Pushing themselves to be more vulnerable even when uncomfortable 😣

friendship.question: {name}'s friends hang out without them and post about it online. What should {name} do?

options.text: Call them out in the group chat 😤
Silently unfollow them all 👻
Make new plans with different friends 🍕
Ask one close friend if there's something wrong 🤔

friendship.question: {name} realizes they're always the one initiating conversations. What's their next move?

options.text: Stop messaging and see if anyone notices 🧪
Keep initiating because that's just their role 🤡
Have an honest conversation about feeling one-sided 💬
Slowly distance themselves and find new friends 🚶

friendship.question: {name} is too tired to socialize but feels guilty canceling plans. What's the move?

options.text: Go anyway and pretend to have energy 🎭
Cancel with a vague excuse about being sick 🤒
Honestly explain they need alone time to recharge 🔋
Just don't show up and deal with it later 👻

friendship.question: {name}'s friend only messages when they need something. How should {name} handle it?

options.text: Always help them because that's what friends do 🤗
Ignore their messages or take forever to reply 🐢
Set boundaries and call out the pattern 🛑
Keep score and only help when they've helped you 📝

friendship.question: When {name} shares good news, their friends change the subject. What does this mean?

options.text: They're jealous of {name}'s success 😒
They didn't hear or understand the importance 🙉
They don't care about {name}'s life 💔
The friendship has different levels of emotional depth 🌊

friendship.question: {name} has 500+ social media friends but feels lonely. What's the real issue?

options.text: They need to post more interesting content 📱
Online connections aren't the same as real friendships 🤖
They should reach out and try to meet up with people 🍵
Everyone feels lonely sometimes, it's normal 🤷

career.question: {name} has an important deadline but doesn't feel motivated. What's their best approach?

options.text: Pull an all-nighter fueled by energy drinks ⚡
Do the minimum required to meet basic expectations 🤏
Break the task into tiny steps and reward progress 🧩
Ask for an extension and hope for the best 🙏

career.question: Everyone around {name} is hustling with side projects. {name} prefers work-life balance. Is this bad?

options.text: Yes, they'll never get ahead with that attitude 📉
No, burnout is real and boundaries are healthy 🧘
Maybe they should try one small project for growth 🌱
They should just pretend to hustle on social media 🤳

career.question: {name} finds a clever shortcut that produces good results with less effort. Should they:

options.text: Keep it secret so they look more productive than others 🤫
Share it with colleagues to improve team efficiency 🤝
Use the extra time for personal projects at work 👨‍💻
Work even harder to really impress the boss 💪

career.question: {name} wants career growth but hates networking events. What's a good strategy?

options.text: Force themselves to attend every event possible 😫
Focus on online networking instead 💻
Build deeper relationships with a few key contacts 🤝
Decide networking isn't for them and hope for the best 🎲

career.question: {name} does the bare minimum at work but delivers quality results. The boss is:

options.text: Frustrated because effort matters more than results 😠
Impressed by their efficiency 👏
Suspicious they're cutting corners somewhere 🧐
Concerned about their lack of ambition 📊

career.question: {name} feels guilty for not being passionate about their job. Should they:

options.text: Find a new job they're passionate about immediately 🚪
Accept that work is just for money and find passion elsewhere 💰
Try to develop more interest by learning new aspects 🌱
Fake enthusiasm to fit in with coworkers 🎭

personality.question: People describe {name} as 'chill' but inside their mind is:

options.text: Actually calm - their thoughts match their appearance 🧘
Complete chaos - 50 browser tabs constantly open 🌪️
Strategic calm - they process chaos before expressing 🧠
Numbness - they don't feel much of anything 🧊

personality.question: {name} acts differently around different friend groups. This means they're:

options.text: Fake and don't know their true self 🎭
Adaptable and socially intelligent 🦎
People-pleasing to an unhealthy degree 😬
Exploring different aspects of their personality 🔍

personality.question: {name} is both extremely organized and hopelessly messy. This contradiction is:

options.text: A sign they need to pick one way of being 🤔
Perfectly normal - humans contain multitudes 🌈
Confusing to others and should be fixed 🔧
A sign they're organized about things they care about 🎯

personality.question: {name} feels like a different person alone vs. with others. This means:

options.text: They're hiding their true self from others 🙈
They have a rich inner life and social awareness 🧠
They haven't found the right people yet 🔍
They should act more consistently in all settings 🤖

personality.question: {name} is described as "hard to read." This is because:

options.text: They intentionally hide their feelings for protection 🛡️
They process emotions internally before sharing 🧠
They don't want to burden others with their emotions 🎭
They actually don't experience strong emotions 🧊
Makes pro/con lists and analyzes logically 📊
Goes with their gut feeling without explanation 🦋
Overthinks until the decision is made for them ⏳
Balances both logic and intuition mindfully 🧘
